 I hold a 'pro-choice' position, but I can't speak for everyone sharing that position and so I'll just give my opinion: It doesn't matter. 
 
 I don't base my pro-choice position on any kind of social engineering argument. I do this for the sake (the value) of consistency because eugenics of that kind infringes on the kind of freedom that I hold most valuable - the freedom to choose. I support a woman's right to choose on principles of personal sovereignty, rather than from any analysis of dubious social benefits or costs that may come from aborting children.
 
 A typical objection to this position is that by aborting a child, we deny it the potential freedom of choice for which life is necessary. I think this is fallacious because even if the child were capable of making a decision, the choice would be the woman's on grounds of it being her body that is being inhabited and depended on. 
 
 A woman's body is her property to dispose of as she sees fit and so forcing her to use her body to support another's life against her will is therefore wrong. Her right to personal sovereignty thus trumps the child's right to personal sovereignty. Her right to personal sovereignty likewise trumps the whims of the father for the same reason that otherwise her property rights are violated. 
 
 On a side note, I wonder why it is that pro-lifers aren't pushing harder for technologies to preserve the life of a child in the case of its ejection from its mother.
